natural problem: Two cubes with the faces numbered 1 through 6 are tossed and the numbers shown on the top faces are added. What is the probability that the sum is even? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: After the first cube has been rolled, the other cube has six possible results. Three are one parity, and three are the other parity, so no matter what the first cube shows, there is a $\boxed{\frac12}$ chance that the sum is either parity.
Note that this is true no matter how many such cubes are rolled.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P_even :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P_even = (\<Sum>(x, y) \<in> {1..6} \<times> {1..6}. if (x + y) mod 2 = 0 then 1 else 0) / (6 * 6)"
shows  "P_even = 1 / 2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two cubes with the faces numbered 1 through 6 are tossed and the numbers shown on the top faces are added. What is the probability that the sum is even? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac12
 ### Proof
 After the first cube has been rolled, the other cube has six possible results. Three are one parity, and three are the other parity, so no matter what the first cube shows, there is a $\boxed{\frac12}$ chance that the sum is either parity.
 Note that this is true no matter how many such cubes are rolled.
 *)

theorem
fixes P_even :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P_even = (\<Sum>(x, y) \<in> {1..6} \<times> {1..6}. if (x + y) mod 2 = 0 then 1 else 0) / (6 * 6)"
shows  "P_even = 1 / 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: What is the probability that the sum of two numbers rolled on two standard six-sided dice is even? The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum> (i::int, j::int) \<in> {1..6} \<times> {1..6}. if even (i + j) then 1 else 0) / 36"
shows  "p = 1/2"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two cubes with the faces numbered 1 through 6 are tossed and the numbers shown on the top faces are added. What is the probability that the sum is even? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac12
 ### Proof
 After the first cube has been rolled, the other cube has six possible results. Three are one parity, and three are the other parity, so no matter what the first cube shows, there is a $\boxed{\frac12}$ chance that the sum is either parity.
 Note that this is true no matter how many such cubes are rolled.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum> (i::int, j::int) \<in> {1..6} \<times> {1..6}. if even (i + j) then 1 else 0) / 36"
shows  "p = 1/2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A die is thrown twice. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers shown on the two dice is even? The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes even_sums total_outcomes :: real
assumes h0 : "even_sums = {a + b | a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> even (a + b)}"
and h1 : "total_outcomes = 36"
shows  "card even_sums / total_outcomes = 1 / 2"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two cubes with the faces numbered 1 through 6 are tossed and the numbers shown on the top faces are added. What is the probability that the sum is even? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac12
 ### Proof
 After the first cube has been rolled, the other cube has six possible results. Three are one parity, and three are the other parity, so no matter what the first cube shows, there is a $\boxed{\frac12}$ chance that the sum is either parity.
 Note that this is true no matter how many such cubes are rolled.
 *)

theorem
fixes even_sums total_outcomes :: real
assumes h0 : "even_sums = {a + b | a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> even (a + b)}"
and h1 : "total_outcomes = 36"
shows  "card even_sums / total_outcomes = 1 / 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a situation where two dice are rolled, find the probability that the sum of the numbers on the two dice is even. The total number of outcomes is 36. The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p_even_sum :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b. 1 \<le> a \<and> a \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> b \<and> b \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> n. a + b = 2 * n)"
shows  "p_even_sum = 1/2"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two cubes with the faces numbered 1 through 6 are tossed and the numbers shown on the top faces are added. What is the probability that the sum is even? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac12
 ### Proof
 After the first cube has been rolled, the other cube has six possible results. Three are one parity, and three are the other parity, so no matter what the first cube shows, there is a $\boxed{\frac12}$ chance that the sum is either parity.
 Note that this is true no matter how many such cubes are rolled.
 *)

theorem
fixes p_even_sum :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b. 1 \<le> a \<and> a \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> b \<and> b \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> n. a + b = 2 * n)"
shows  "p_even_sum = 1/2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: What is the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled on two fair six-sided dice is an even number? The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> probability k = 1/6"
and h1 : "sum probability {2, 4, 6} = 1/2"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>k. probability (k + k)) {1..6} = 1/2"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two cubes with the faces numbered 1 through 6 are tossed and the numbers shown on the top faces are added. What is the probability that the sum is even? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac12
 ### Proof
 After the first cube has been rolled, the other cube has six possible results. Three are one parity, and three are the other parity, so no matter what the first cube shows, there is a $\boxed{\frac12}$ chance that the sum is either parity.
 Note that this is true no matter how many such cubes are rolled.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> probability k = 1/6"
and h1 : "sum probability {2, 4, 6} = 1/2"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>k. probability (k + k)) {1..6} = 1/2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A fair six-sided die is rolled, with each face showing a number from 1 to 6. Each number has an equal probability of $\frac{1}{6}$ of being rolled. What is the probability of rolling an even number, i.e., 2, 4, or 6? The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P_even :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P_even = (\<Sum>(a, b)\<in>{(a, b) | a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> even (a + b)} . 1) / (\<Sum>(a, b)\<in>{(a, b) | a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6}} . 1)"
shows  "P_even = 1 / 2"
a_5.formal solution:

 Note that this is true no matter how many such cubes are rolled.
 *)

theorem
fixes P_even :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P_even = (\<Sum>(a, b)\<in>{(a, b) | a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> even (a + b)} . 1) / (\<Sum>(a, b)\<in>{(a, b) | a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6}} . 1)"
shows  "P_even = 1 / 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a game where two fair six-sided dice are rolled, find the probability that the sum of the two dice is even. The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x / 36) * (\<Sum>i = 1..6. \<Sum>j = 1..6. if even (i + j) then 1 else 0)"
shows  "P 2 + P 4 + P 6 + P 8 + P 10 + P 12 = 1 / 2"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two cubes with the faces numbered 1 through 6 are tossed and the numbers shown on the top faces are added. What is the probability that the sum is even? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac12
 ### Proof
 After the first cube has been rolled, the other cube has six possible results. Three are one parity, and three are the other parity, so no matter what the first cube shows, there is a $\boxed{\frac12}$ chance that the sum is either parity.
 Note that this is true no matter how many such cubes are rolled.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x / 36) * (\<Sum>i = 1..6. \<Sum>j = 1..6. if even (i + j) then 1 else 0)"
shows  "P 2 + P 4 + P 6 + P 8 + P 10 + P 12 = 1 / 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Define a function P(x) as the sum of all even sums of i and j, where i and j range from 1 to 6, times the fraction x/36. Find the sum of P(2), P(4), P(6), P(8), P(10), and P(12). The final answer is 1/2.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> probability n = 1/6"
and h1 : "setsum probability {n. \<exists>x y. x \<ge> 1 \<and> x \<le> 6 \<and> y \<ge> 1 \<and> y \<le> 6 \<and> n = x + y \<and> even n} = P"
shows  "P = 1/2"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two cubes with the faces numbered 1 through 6 are tossed and the numbers shown on the top faces are added. What is the probability that the sum is even? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac12
 ### Proof
 After the first cube has been rolled, the other cube has six possible results. Three are one parity, and three are the other parity, so no matter what the first cube shows, there is a $\boxed{\frac12}$ chance that the sum is either parity.
 Note that this is true no matter how many such cubes are rolled.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> probability n = 1/6"
and h1 : "setsum probability {n. \<exists>x y. x \<ge> 1 \<and> x \<le> 6 \<and> y \<ge> 1 \<and> y \<le> 6 \<and> n = x + y \<and> even n} = P"
shows  "P = 1/2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a fair six-sided die, each number from 1 to 6 has a probability of $\frac{1}{6}$ of being rolled. What is the probability of rolling two dice and getting an even sum? The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes even_sum_prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> even_sum_prob"
and h1 : "even_sum_prob \<le> 1"
and h2 : "even_sum_prob = card { (a::nat, b::nat) | a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> even (a + b) } / card ({1..6} \<times> {1..6})"
shows  "even_sum_prob = 1/2"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two cubes with the faces numbered 1 through 6 are tossed and the numbers shown on the top faces are added. What is the probability that the sum is even? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac12
 ### Proof
 After the first cube has been rolled, the other cube has six possible results. Three are one parity, and three are the other parity, so no matter what the first cube shows, there is a $\boxed{\frac12}$ chance that the sum is either parity.
 Note that this is true no matter how many such cubes are rolled.
 *)

theorem
fixes even_sum_prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> even_sum_prob"
and h1 : "even_sum_prob \<le> 1"
and h2 : "even_sum_prob = card { (a::nat, b::nat) | a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> even (a + b) } / card ({1..6} \<times> {1..6})"
shows  "even_sum_prob = 1/2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: What is the probability of getting an even sum when rolling two six-sided dice? The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P k = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "independent_events P P"
shows  "P (\<lambda>x. even (x + y)) = 1 / 2"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two cubes with the faces numbered 1 through 6 are tossed and the numbers shown on the top faces are added. What is the probability that the sum is even? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac12
 ### Proof
 After the first cube has been rolled, the other cube has six possible results. Three are one parity, and three are the other parity, so no matter what the first cube shows, there is a $\boxed{\frac12}$ chance that the sum is either parity.
 Note that this is true no matter how many such cubes are rolled.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P k = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "independent_events P P"
shows  "P (\<lambda>x. even (x + y)) = 1 / 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider a probability function $P$ such that for every integer $k$ in the range $1 \leq k \leq 6$, $P(k) = \frac{1}{6}$. If the events described by $P$ are independent, what is the probability that the sum of two events $x$ and $y$ is even? The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.
